urn:contentItem:5Y8M-K3Y1-JCDN-11W9-00000-00Japan criticises US digital tax proposal at G202020-02-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:03:52ZLexisNexisBUSINESSJapan criticises US digital tax proposal at G20

RIYADH: Japanese finance minister Taro Aso criticized on Sunday a U.S. tax reform proposal that he said could undermine global efforts to agree new rules on taxing big tech companies. The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development(OECD) is developing rules to make digital companies pay tax where they do business, rather than where they register subsidiaries - a move that was broadly endorsed by finance leaders of the Group of 20 (G20) major economies on Sunday. Yet the OECD efforts were stalled late last year by last-minute changes demanded by Washington, including a proposed "safe harbor" regime which critics say would let multinationals choose whether to abide by the new set of rules or stick to existing regulations.

"I told my counterparts that Japan is very concerned about the 'safe harbor' proposal," Aso told reporters after attending the G20 gathering. "It would extremely diminish the regulatory effect of what we're trying to do. That is a view expressed by various countries," he said, joining a chorus of criticism by France and other nations over the U.S. proposal. Many G20 officials view the United States as reluctant to deal with a potentially tricky political matter before the presidential election later this year. It is rare for Japan to openly criticize the United States on economic policy, given the two countries' close defense ties. The taxing of global digital firms such as Amazon, Google and Apple - and the effect of the coronavirus outbreak on the global economy - have figured prominently at the weekend gathering of G20 finance leaders in Riyadh. In a communique issued after the meeting, finance leaders said they encouraged further progress in narrowing remaining differences towards reaching a consensus on the tax issue by end of 2020. The OECD says the measure could boost national tax revenues by a total of US$100 billion a year. - Reuters

urn:contentItem:5XSB-DCH1-F17J-S18N-00000-00Japan government eyes tighter rules on personal data2019-12-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:03:52ZLexisNexisJapan government eyes tighter rules on personal dataDaisuke Ichikawa, Utai Hatani

A government panel on competition in the digital marketplace has proposed regulations on large technology companies that would require stricter controls on personal information as businesses expand their use of personal data.

However, as the use of data will play a key role in the development of digital societies, the panel wants to ensure the regulations also respect corporate autonomy and do not hinder technological innovation. 

Data collection

One of the ways giant tech companies profit is by collecting and analyzing huge amounts of user data from free services such as maps, online searches and social networks, then using this to sell advertising. 

Users often do not realize their data is being collected, and it is becoming more difficult for people to understand how their information is being used. 

There is also a risk of data leaks. In 2018, it was discovered that personal data from up to about 87 million people had leaked from Facebook Inc.

‘Dominant position’

In response, the draft revision of the personal information protection law broadens individual rights by allowing users to request companies stop using their data.

The aim is to apply the prohibition on “abusing a dominant bargaining position,” which in antitrust law mainly functions between companies, to consumers. 

Collecting and using “cookies,” which record what websites users have viewed, could be regarded as an abuse of this dominant position if they can be used to identify individuals and are acquired and used without notifying users. 

The job site Rikunabi, run by Recruit Career Co., got into trouble for selling data to companies on the probability that job seekers would decline informal job offers.

Initially, the site’s use of cookies to identify individuals was what was seen as problematic. 

However, EY Advisory & Consulting Co.’s Izumi Umezawa said the regulations needed to go farther.

“This revision [of the law] would be a step forward, but without things like the ‘right to be forgotten,’ it's lacking,” he said, referring to protections that allow people to demand some online content, such as slander, be removed. 

Path to better use

Meanwhile, other measures were also under consideration in order to encourage companies to better use data.

The regulations also present a new concept — “alias data.”

The idea is that if data can be processed so the individual cannot be identified, such as by substituting part of it, companies or other groups could use it internally to make predictions about attributes and preferences, even without the individual's consent.

In principle, if data is not processed so there is no way to identify the individual, it cannot be used. 

Industry objects

A draft of the provisionally named Digital Platform Transaction Transparency Law stipulates that large tech companies must regularly submit reports to the government on areas such as the status of transactions. 

In the market for online sales and smartphone apps, the reality is that companies cannot do business without the service infrastructure provided by the giant tech firms.

Even if they are unhappy, it is difficult for these businesses to object to things like unilateral fee increases. 

The draft law obligates large tech companies to submit reports, making it easier to understand the state of such transactions. 

Globally, such requirements are rare and some doubts have been raised. 

Hiroshi Mikitani, chairman and president of Rakuten Inc., which operates the online shopping platform Rakuten Ichiba, strongly criticized the government’s stance, saying, “In the midst of an internet revolution, they’re putting regulations on everything and requiring reports to the state.” 

An official related to the government explained that, “We want to create a framework that encourages the big tech firms to think about things they can do voluntarily, rather than having the government giving orders when there's a problem with a client.”

urn:contentItem:5XSB-B741-JCF4-6181-00000-00Japan in Depth;Govt eyes new rules on personal data2019-12-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:03:52ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. 1;Japan in DepthGovt eyes new rules on personal dataDaisuke Ichikawa and Utai HataniYomiuri Shimbun Staff Writers

A government panel on competition in the digital marketplace has proposed regulations on large technology companies that would require stricter controls on personal information as businesses expand their use of personal data.

However, as the use of data will play a key role in the development of digital societies, the panel wants to ensure the regulations also respect corporate autonomy and do not hinder technological innovation.

Data collection

One of the ways giant tech companies profit is by collecting and analyzing huge amounts of user data from free services such as maps, online searches and social networks, then using this to sell advertising.

Users often do not realize their data is being collected, and it is becoming more difficult for people to understand how their information is being used.

There is also a risk of data leaks. In 2018, it was discovered that personal data from up to about 87 million people had leaked from Facebook Inc.

'Dominant position'

In response, the draft revision of the personal information protection law broadens individual rights by allowing users to request companies stop using their data.

The aim is to apply the prohibition on "abusing a dominant bargaining position," which in antitrust law mainly functions between companies, to consumers.

Collecting and using "cookies," which record what websites users have viewed, could be regarded as an abuse of this dominant position if they can be used to identify individuals and are acquired and used without notifying users.

The job site Rikunabi, run by Recruit Career Co., got into trouble for selling data to companies on the probability that job seekers would decline informal job offers.

Initially, the site's use of cookies to identify individuals was what was seen as problematic.

However, EY Advisory & Consulting Co.'s Izumi Umezawa said the regulations needed to go farther.

"This revision [of the law] would be a step forward, but without things like the 'right to be forgotten,' it's lacking," he said, referring to protections that allow people to demand some online content, such as slander, be removed.

Path to better use

Meanwhile, other measures were also under consideration in order to encourage companies to better use data.

The regulations also present a new concept -- "alias data."

The idea is that if data can be processed so the individual cannot be identified, such as by substituting part of it, companies or other groups could use it internally to make predictions about attributes and preferences, even without the individual's consent.

In principle, if data is not processed so there is no way to identify the individual, it cannot be used.

Industry objects

A draft of the provisionally named Digital Platform Transaction Transparency Law stipulates that large tech companies must regularly submit reports to the government on areas such as the status of transactions.

In the market for online sales and smartphone apps, the reality is that companies cannot do business without the service infrastructure provided by the giant tech firms.

Even if they are unhappy, it is difficult for these businesses to object to things like unilateral fee increases.

The draft law obligates large tech companies to submit reports, making it easier to understand the state of such transactions.

Globally, such requirements are rare and some doubts have been raised.

Hiroshi Mikitani, chairman and president of Rakuten Inc., which operates the online shopping platform Rakuten Ichiba, strongly criticized the government's stance, saying, "In the midst of an internet revolution, they're putting regulations on everything and requiring reports to the state."

An official related to the government explained that, "We want to create a framework that encourages the big tech firms to think about things they can do voluntarily, rather than having the government giving orders when there's a problem with a client."

Ford CIO Tim Stone on Ford's Business; New Screening at AirportsJackie DeAngelis, Cheryl Casone, Kristina Partsinevelos

JACKIE DEANGELIS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Hi, I'm Jackie DeAngelis, in for Maria Bartiromo today. It is Monday, August 17. Your top stories at 7 AM Eastern. The race for the White House. The Democratic National Convention kicking off today virtually and President Trump heading to Wisconsin for a campaign blitz.

What new polls are showing in battleground states and the postal service is in focus. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi forcing lawmakers back to Washington, to address what she calls sabotage of mail-in voting. House Minority Whip Steve Scalise joins me next hour to discuss when and if a compromise could be reached.

American cities in crisis. Seattle declaring a riot overnight after Portland and Chicago were slammed by violence, this weekend. The markets are looking to start the week to the upside. Features edging higher. You can see the DOW indicated higher by 59. The NASDAQ 68 and the S&P 500 by 10. This after markets finished with little change on Friday but the S&P 500 still within striking distance of its record closing high.

And later this hour, an exclusive interview with Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross. He's got a major announcement tied to China. You don't want to miss that. Retail of course in focus this week. Earnings expected from heavy hitters including Walmart, Home Depot, Lowe's and Target.

And the state of travel. Airports now bracing for a whole new world of changes at check in. What you need to know before you head to the airport and mortgage rates still at an all-time low. Could they finally reaches zero percent? We're going to take a look at that. Mornings with Maria is live right now.

Good morning everyone. European markets looking a little bit higher this morning. The Footsie higher by 40. The CAC Quarante by 3. The DAX index higher by 36 points. This as investors are keeping their focus on travel restrictions, trade tensions between the U.S. and China as well.

In Asia overnight, it was a little bit of a mixed bag. The Shanghai was the best performing index. The KOSPI closed for a holiday. The Japanese economy in focus contracting a record rate of 27.8 percent between April and June. This was brought on by weak spending and also trade issues.

Joining the conversation all morning Lee Carter, Jonathan Madison and Mitch Roschelle. Great to see you guys. Meantime some of the top stories that we're watching this morning include the Democratic National Convention kicking off tonight. It's virtual for the first time ever. Cheryl Casone has more.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: That's right Jackie and this is a historic week that begins tonight. Democrats say that are going to focus not one, on the three major crises they say face the nation, the pandemic, the economy and racial injustice. Now if virtual speeches from Senator Bernie Sanders, former Ohio Governor John Kasich, 2016 Republican we should say who ran for president and he had been critical of President Trump.

He's going to be speaking. The keynote speaker is going to be former First Lady Michelle Obama. A new national poll is showing Joe Biden is holding only a one percent lead over President Trump right now in 15 key battleground states.

Well, violence overnight in Seattle, chaos in the downtown area. Rioters took to the streets for an anti-police rally. Several officers were injured in the melee. At least 18 people were arrested there.

And coronavirus deaths in the United States now surpassing 170,000. New York City's Tribute of Lights 9/11 Memorial is going to happen by the way after all. New York Governor Andrew Cuomo says the state will provide the support needed to set up the night time display.

Last month officials had canceled the event over coronavirus concerns but an uproar seems to have changed their minds. Well, lightning and heat behind the cause of several new fires in southern California. Five are currently burning including the lake fire which is still only 12 percent contained.

High temperature is not helping the situation there and in Death Valley over the weekend, the mercury reached 130 degrees. That is the hottest temperature believed on earth in more than 100 years and there's your headlines, Jackie.

DEANGELIS: Thanks so much Cheryl. Meantime, it's time for the word on Wall Street. A look at what top market experts are watching this morning as we kick off the week. Joining me now ER Shares CEO, Joel Shulman and Bulltick Capital Market's head of research Kathryn Rooney Vera.

Kathryn, let's go ahead and start with you because Cheryl highlighted the key speakers at the DNC kicking off today. A lot of star power there if you will, I'm wondering what you think the markets are going to think about the conventions kicking off virtually, how different it's going to be, you've got a Biden-Harris ticket right now.

The Wall Street journal is saying you know traders are bracing for a lot of volatility as we head into this election period.

KATHRYN ROONEY VERA, HEAD OF GLOBAL RESEARCH, BULLTICK CAPITAL MARKETS: Well, the market now is more than a quarter attached to five stocks so those five stocks which are principally technology stocks, I think are where the market is going to have its laser-like focus, Jackie and that is with regard to the potential for anti-trust yet onerous regulatory burden that could come up and that could be in the fore under a Biden-Harris administration.

One of the things I'm looking for is who will be Treasury Secretary and my bet is it would be Elizabeth Warren. If that's the case, the markets will not like that and especially the banking sector as well as in the healthcare sector so these are things that I think the market is keenly interested, especially with regard to tax in position.

So the stocks that have moved the S&P to these lofty levels are vulnerable under the next administration.

DEANGELIS: Kathryn, now that Harris is officially on the ticket, you look at these markets, not really reacting much, kind of continuing on with the recovery after you know as we're dealing with the coronavirus pandemic, not really reacting to the choice there.

And I'm wondering if you think that you know how long it takes before the markets start to look at some of the policies coming from the democratic ticket saying this can really have an impact here because these numbers are not reflecting that.

ROONEY VERA: The markets are remarkably resilient, Jackie and one thing I'll tell you as a as a strategist, as a market economist myself is that you have to deal with the combination of both what fundamentals tell you and what the scene can change over the course of the next year and a massive backstop by a price insensitive buyer which is the Federal Reserve.

So if we get a drop in the market, that's a big if, under the next administration once we get these policy moves and the market's internalization of how detrimental they can effectively be for small businesses and big businesses alike, we have to deal with the Fed so at what point does the Fed then decide that too much is too much of a selloff?

It is already engaged in the purchase of high yield bond, what's to deter the Fed from moving from high yield bonds into U.S. equities?

DEANGELIS: Well, it's a good point but I also want to sort of focus in and look at the features this morning because we've got a slight gain on our hands as we're getting ready for the trading session. Investors are eyeing retail earnings set for this week. We've got Walmart, we've got Home Depot, Target, other big names, all reporting their results.

This is coming after July retail spending numbers showed that American shopping rose higher than pre-pandemic levels so Joel, I'm wondering what you think you know, the bar was lowered for these retail companies, the numbers aren't necessarily going to be great but the good news is that the consumer is back out there and that's really what is going to drive this recovery, going forward.

JOEL SHULMAN, CEO, ER SHARES: Right, well as your viewers know, I mean we're at record levels across the board. The S&P is still - hasn't broken through but we're seeing a lot of movement not only the U. S. markets in small cap, they went up about 10.5 percent last month but we're seeing a lot of money moving off shore now $2.9 billion moved last week.

That follows $2 billion the prior week and $2 billion the week before that so we're seeing a big movement to offshore, 2.5 percent or 2.47 percent up last month. Last week in the non U.S. markets and even in the non-U.S. small caps were especially bullish on those. They were off almost 9 percent last month, just a little bit behind the U.S. small caps.

So we believe U.S. small caps and we believe non-U.S. particularly non U.S. small caps can particularly be strong and we see news continuing to push through to probably till number.

DEANGELIS: So if you had new capital to put to work and you're looking at this market and you know technology has been on fire, you know is that necessarily where you'd go? The non U.S. stocks, the small cap stocks, the journal writing that the cyclicals are starting to take off and that shows sort of the breadth of the rally taking place here which is important when you really think of a recovery in the scheme of things.

SHULMAN: Right, we've seen this before by the way. We've seen cyclicals, you'll have a run, people thought it was going to go from growth to value. It lasted for about a week and then went right back so we think and we realize that last week was a strong week for the circles but we've seen this before.

I believe some of the tech long term are still in good place for investors and we really see - and we're seeing flows in a big way going offshore and am particularly non-U.S. small cap. That's what we will put on, small cap U.S. and non U.S., particularly non- U.S. small cap offshore.

DEANGELIS: All right, well, it is those small cap, it is the industrials. We saw them surging so far this August. The Wall Street journal saying that the investors are seeing this as the breadth that I mentioned, that the range is widening after months of dominance by those big tech companies, Amazon, Google, Facebook, the like.

Joining us is Washington Crossing Advisors, Market Strategist and Portfolio Manager Kevin Caron. Kevin, great to see you. I want to get your take on the markets as investors are sort of setting up for this Monday, so much going on. We're watching a coronavirus, the recovery, vaccines, we're watching the DNC kicking off tonight. What's the most important thing and where would you be allocating capital?

KEVIN CARON, MARKET STRATEGIST, WASHINGTON CROSSING ADVISORS: The most important thing is that market sentiment and the good feeling that the market has been enjoying the last couple of months, continues and begins to spill over into real economic data.

So since March, we've seen a tremendous inpouring of stimulus money into the economy, just about exactly offsetting the decline in nominal GDP that we've seen in the private sector but then beyond that, we've also seen tremendous support by central banks and we're getting additional support globally by Bank of China for example.

So this has been very nice. It's been good to see investors holding there with reasonably decent levels of confidence, funded by cheap money but this now has to accelerate to the broader economy where we would expect to see leadership brought now away from groups like technology and really some safe assets like gold and long term treasury bonds for example have simultaneously rallied along with technology, which is kind of an interesting trait.

But that trade has to break one way or the other. Either things truly get better or those insurance assets like gold and treasuries are going to become more - more desirable for market participants.

DEANGELIS: All right, Joel Shulman, Kathryn Rooney Vera, Kevin Caron, thank you so much guys. Coming up New York Congressman Tom Reed on House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's calling lawmakers back to Washington over the Postal service. Plus a Fox Business exclusive with Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross with the latest on how the United States is taking on China. Covid-19 of course changing air travel, airports bracing for new safety measures.

Then in the 8:00 hour, House Minority Whip Steve Scalise on the House battle over the Postal service. Former Connecticut Senator and vice presidential candidate Joe Lieberman previewing in the Democratic National Convention which is kicking off tonight.

Trump 2020 presidential campaign National Press Secretary Hogan Gidley on a President Trump's campaign blitz as he heads to Wisconsin which is a key battleground state and how low can they go? How extremely low mortgage rates are affecting the housing market. You are watching Mornings with Maria, live on Fox Business.

DEANGELIS: Return from recess. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi calling lawmakers back to Washington to address U.S. Postal service cuts, ahead of the November election, including removing mailboxes and sorting machines around the country. White House Chief of Staff Mark Meadows signaling yesterday that President Trump would be willing to sign a bill supporting the USPS, as long as stimulus checks and PPP funding are included as well.

Joining me now New York Congressman and House problem-solvers caucus co- chair Tom Reed, good morning, great to see you.

REP. TOM REED (R-NY): Good to be with you. Thanks for having me on.

DEANGELIS: Let's go ahead and start first with the postal service and Nancy Pelosi calling everybody back to make sure the service could be funded. The Democrats making a real push here to see if mail-in ballots can go off without a hitch for this election while you've got the president, he's got a 100 different fires that he's dealing with on his plate right now and stimulus is first and foremost.

They're saying that he's purposely trying to sabotage the Post Office. Your thoughts.

REED: That's ridiculous. This isn't about sabotaging the Post Office. This is about recognizing what universal mail-in, that's different than absentee ballot and they're trying to mix the two together. When you talk about universal ballot, that means everybody - they're going to make everyone get a ballot in America regardless if they request for it or not. That is just logistically almost next to impossible given the nature of how many ballots we're talking about.

So there's a real problem there and so when we go back this weekend, I hope we don't just focus on the Post Office. The American people are suffering and it's about time to put the American people's interest first and get a deal done for them.

DEANGELIS: Well, you bring up a great point, right? Sort of a stimulus stalemate right now as this Post Office conversation goes on. Bipartisan House lawmakers are speaking with the White House Chief of Staff Mark Meadows over the weekend, discussing moving forward with coronavirus aid and the talks with it.

Despite some of the setbacks that we've seen, a potential deal could be weeks away. You were on that call with Meadows, your reaction to this as Nancy Pelosi is saying, let's get the House back to vote on the Post Office but we're not worried and that election by the way, is 2.5 months away.

We're not worried about the Americans that are suffering right now that need those stimulus checks.

REED: That's what's so disappointing. When you don't put the American people's interest first and you worry about politics as your priority, that's what's happened and that's why I'm proud of the problem-solver caucus members that organically reached out when this deal broke down and said, we're not going to accept this.

And so we work behind the scenes and we reached out and the White House reached out to us when they heard that we were talking in a bipartisan fashion and we were able to set up communications with the White House. Those communications continue to today and I'll just tell you, we're going to continue to use our relationships based on trust, exchanging substantive information and get a deal done for the American people because that's who we work for.

We don't work to win elections, we work for the American people.

DEANGELIS: Lee, jump in.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, POLLSTER AND MASLANSKY + PARTNERS: Yes, I think it's really important because whichever party ends up being the party that is considered to be on the side of the American people getting the economy going, I think is ultimately going to win this election. Some of the most important issues are economic safety right now. People going back to work.

On the other hand I know there are a lot of people who are concerned about how they're going to vote in November. Voter enthusiasm is at an all-time high and many people are afraid to go to the polls so how do you address that and how do you respond to them because I think it is important issue that we can't just -

REED: That's why I've always been supportive of the Post Office in recognizing that Covid-19 requires us to recognize that people have a fear and rightfully so of the virus and so they have to have access to the ability to vote, not only in person but also by mail and other - other tools that are available to people in the individual states.

And so making sure the Post Office has the necessary resources and that's why talking to Mark Meadows and other folks and you've already over the weekend, a commentary about making sure the Post Office has the resources that handle those folks that want to use absentee ballots and those tools, have access to them.

That's an appropriate conversation but this idea that we're going to run our entire election, regardless if you request a ballot or not, that you get a ballot delivered to you, regardless if you ask for one or not, that's what universal mail-in balloting is all about and that is where the potential fraud is used and as the American people figure that out and get educated on it, they will have that same concern that we have about making sure that if you're going to abuse the system and use those ballots that are floating around unrecorded, that you go to jail if you if you bring our election loss and that that is the counterbalance to.

Some and use those ballots are floating around on recorded that you go to jail if you break our election laws and that is the counterbalance to where this needs to go.

DEANGELIS: Congressman Tom Reed, we're going to have to leave it there. Thank you so much for your time this morning.

REED: Thanks for having me on. We'll get through this.

DEANGELIS: We will. We will get through this as a country. Thank you. Coming up, Steve Bannon next on what President Trump needs to do to win in November. Plus coronavirus is changing air travel so those airports bracing for new safety measures. You are watching Mornings with Maria out live on Fox Business.

DEANGELIS: Countdown to November. Maria Bartiromo speaking with former White House Chief Strategist Steve Bannon on Sunday Morning Futures, yesterday. Asking him about the Biden-Harris ticket and what their economic priorities look like. Listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: One of those policies is higher taxes. The Wall Street Journal writes, under Biden's tax cut - tax increases, a married couple filing jointly shows $78,000 of ordinary income, their current marginal rate is 12 percent when Trumps tax cut expires, their marginal rate under Biden would double to 25 percent.

This is just a couple filing $78,000 in ordinary income. What are your thoughts on Biden's choice of Kamala Harris and real quick, isn't that interesting that John Kasich is one of the speakers on Monday night. He's kicking off the DNC. John Kasich.

STEVE BANNON, FMR WHITE HOUSE CHIEF STRATEGIST: Well, this shows you that never-Trump crowd, how they're triggered by President Trump. John Kasich is one. He's a quisling, OK? Everything he's ever stood for his entire life, everything his supporters gave him, he's going to stand up there on Monday night and basically throw it all away. OK, because these policies are so radical.

The globalization projects are so radical by these Democrats, now with undergirding of this culture of Marxism so no, I think Biden picked the perfect candidate for him because I think it's so juxtaposed to what President Trump stands for. I think Senator Harris is the perfect running mate for him because now you can show the globalization.

Remember and with Biden, you don't have a Manchurian candidate, you have a Beijing candidate, the victory right here for President Trump is very specific. It goes right through Beijing. You hold him accountable for the pandemic, you hold him accountable for the economic carnage for all the deaths, you start to confront the Chinese Communist Party everywhere, in technology, in economics and what they're doing is start to bring back the supply chain.

You start to bring back high value added manufacturing jobs. That is the path to victory. Joe Biden is in cahoots. He's compromised by Beijing, he's compromised by the Chinese Communist Party. Senator Harris is basically a cipher on this so they're not going to be able to combat that.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DEANGELIS: A lot to unpack there. Jonathan, I want to go straight to you and start with the tax portion of it. You know we're not talking about a huge salary as Maria was talking about there. Yet we're talking about a doubling in taxes. Do people really understand what the Biden-Harris ticket's economic policies would look like and how it's going to impact them you know in their pocketbook?

JONATHAN MADISON, REPUBLICAN STRATEGIST: No, I don't think they understand but it's only a matter of time and from what I've been reading, you're getting tremendous amounts of pressure from the Left for Biden to adopt policies like Medicare for all and the New Green Deal which would increase taxes substantially.

We're talking corporate taxes, capital gains taxes, payroll taxes and strategically, I think all the president needs to do to win is to stress the economy and remind people about the 2017 legendary tax cuts he made for all working Americans.

We're talking about Americans at the lower end of the socio economic spectrum as well so I think in all situation here, it's going to come down to the President reminding people that in contrast to the far left's plan for the economy, even the current policies that Biden has in mind right now in contrast to his, that the president a 3.5 percent unemployment rate in September 2019, lowest in 50 years.

I think if you contrast that, the American people will wake up and start to understand.

DEANGELIS: And Lee, the messaging on the Left with the DNC, Bannon pointed out is going to be sort of a message of globalization whereas the Trump administration is going to focus on its economic policies which pre- pandemic were doing pretty well and we do have a what looks to be like a V- shaped recovery on our hands now and there's still time leading into the election. It seems like with respect to economic matters, the president is very well positioned.

CARTER: There's no question about it. It is the one area that he polls the best and I think that when you look at polling right now and there's a lot of your debate on how accurate polling is but one thing we do know for sure is only 30 percent of Americans feel like they really know Joe Biden and what he's going to for America.

His polling is entirely based on two-third saying the reason that they support Joe Biden is because he is against Donald Trump. So what has to happen now is Joe Biden needs to make the case on what does Joe Biden's America look like.

Is it about globalization? Is it about just being better than Trump? I don't think being better than Trump is enough to win and if Trump is able to make the case that his economy - he's the one who is going to fight for the America people, if he's the one actually that's been on relief for the American people in this moment, he's going to be the one that's going to win in November and I think it's going to be a big surprise to the Democrats.

Because I think many of them can't imagine that Trump would win again. I also think that we're going to have to look at the convention as we can see how much time spent reacting to Donald Trump because that will tell you who's winning by the one who is acting, not reacting.

DEANGELIS: Guys, thank you. We're going to have to leave it there for the moment but coming up on the show, a Fox Business exclusive with Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross with the latest on how the U.S. is taking on China.

Plus Ford is rolling on. The auto maker weathering the Covid-19 pandemic. We are taking a look at what's new there. You're watching Mornings with Maria, live on Fox Business.

JACKIE DEANGELIS, FBN ANCHOR: Welcome back. I'm Jackie DeAngelis, in for Maria Bartiromo today.

It is Monday, August 17th.

A look at the markets at 7:30 a.m. Eastern Time.

We're seeing the Dow indicated higher. The futures are edging higher there by 73 points. The Nasdaq by 73 as well. And the S&P 500 by 11.

Now this after markets were little changed on Friday. The S&P 500, though, still less than half of one percent away from its all-time record high.

European markets are higher across the board as well. The FTSE higher by 37 points. The CAC quarante up by 6. The DAX up by 32. And investors are keeping their focus on travel restrictions and also U.S./China trade tensions.

In Asia overnight it was a bit of a mixed story. The Shanghai was the best performing index. The Kospi was closed for a holiday. And the focus has been also on the Japanese economy contracting a record rate of 27.8 percent between April and June. This was spurred by weak spending and, of course, trade issues also.

But a dip in travel is prompting a new round of job cuts.

Cheryl Casone has the details on that.

Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Yes, Jackie.

Rolls-Royce is going to close its aircraft parts factory in Prince Georgia County, Virginia, by the middle of next year. At least 280 people are going to be out of a job there. This comes amid a slowdown in global travel due to the coronavirus pandemic. The factory produces jet engine disks and other parts for the British company.

Well, AutoZone is hiring 20,000 workers nationwide as it tries to keep up with demand from retail and commercial customers. The company says it has openings for delivery drivers, part sales manager and sales associates at stores in all 50 states.

And watch out Apple, watch out Zoom, messaging app Telegram is launching a video calling service with end to end encryptions. This allows using to chat and multitask while use this new service. An alpha version of the feature are going to be available on both the iPhone and the android apps. Taking a look at Apple and Zoom in the pre-market. Both stocks are slightly higher, Jackie.

And those are your headlines.

DEANGELIS: Cheryl Casone, thank you.

And we are focusing on the Huawei debate, taking it on specifically in a "Fox Business Exclusive" this morning. The Commerce Department is announcing that further restricting Chinese telecom giants from access to U.S. technology. It's adding 38 non-U.S. Huawei affiliates to the entity list and imposing license requirements on any export transaction that falls under the Commerce Department's jurisdiction.

Joining me now in a "Fox Business Exclusive," Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross.

Secretary, good morning.

WILBUR ROSS, COMMERCE SECRETARY: Good morning, Jackie.

DEANGELIS: Let's talk a little bit first about this new announcement and -- and how it's sort of helping us protect national security by being tougher on Huawei.

ROSS: Well, on May 20th, we issued an order that prevented American technology from being used in Huawei designed chips. That led them to do some evasive measures. They were going through third parties. They were doing things like having people incorporated into other products.

The new rule makes it clear that any use of American software or American fabrication equipment to produce things through Huawei is banned and requires a license. So it's really a question of closing loopholes to prevent a bad actor from access to U.S. technology, even as they try to do it in a very indirect, very tricky manner.

DEANGELIS: And president and the administration, including yourself, have made no bones about taking a very tough stance on China. This was as we were negotiating that phase one trade deal.

But there are trade talks that are pausing at the moment. U.S. and Chinese officials postponing a meeting to discuss progress on that phase one trade deal. Reports on a delay site scheduling conflict, as well as allowing some more time for Chinese purchase of U.S. exports. Reports last week indicate that Chinese officials aim to address the administration's movement on tech companies, like TikTok and WeChat as well.

Secretary, is there a date on the books for another meeting soon or have these talks, you know, stalled amid all the issues that we're dealing with, with China right now?

ROSS: Well, there's a lot of conversation at various levels all of the time. So it is correct that the Chinese have lately been buying a very large amount of agriculture. That's a very good thing. We're very eager to have that continue.

So the -- what action we're taking on Huawei is a trade enforcement, an export control enforcement action. It's not really directly related to the trade talks.

DEANGELIS: The president, of course, taking more action against Chinese tech giants. President Trump indicating on Saturday that he would be willing to put pressure on more Chinese companies, including e-commerce giant Alibaba, after he's made these moves to ban TikTok and WeChat from the United States.

Secretary, I'm wondering, does the Commerce Department have any plans to further restrict Alibaba at this time?

ROSS: Well, right now we are operating under the president's executive order which gives us another few weeks to figure out exactly what it is that TikTok will be banned from doing in the event that they don't sell the company to Microsoft or another American producer. So we're very busy with that.

There's been no formal proceeding of this moment against Alibaba, so there's really nothing we can comment on that score.

DEANGELIS: I want to bring the conversation back to some of these restrictions on Huawei and also, you know, the president's taking on China and general and really addressing the issue that we have with 5G and their developments, you know, saying that the United States should be making more progress in this area, that it's about bandwidth and possibly even freeing up some of that bandwidth, you know, when it comes to military operations to make that possible, to pave that way.

How do you think that that's going to look as we head into the end of the year?

ROSS: Well, it is the case that U.S. has devoted more bandwidth already to 5G than any other country. And there's some further auctions (ph) planned (ph) by the Federal Communications Commission. So we will definitely not be short of bandwidth.

Some parts of the band are very good for rapid transmission of limited amounts of data. Others are good for a little bit slower transmission of vast amount. So bandwidth is not an undifferentiated mask. There are different parts of it that are particularly good at particularly different segments of 5G. But 5G is the target of the new rules that we have put into effect, and those rules will level the playing field so that there's no disadvantage for American software or equipment people relative to the foreigners. Everybody will be on a level playing field. Everybody will be restricted.

DEANGELIS: And that's the -- the key here, right, symmetry in the rules so that everybody is playing by the same rulebook. And -- and that's the problem that we've had with China for so long. And this is the first president to say, I'm going actually do something about it. And he is, Secretary.

ROSS: Well, that's right. The Chinese have been spoiled for decades by American administration that really took no action. Everyone knew what was going on. Everybody talked about doing something. Only President Trump has acted decisively.

And that's true not just with Huawei. It's true with trade in general. Trade both with China, trade with other parties. It's true with a relationship of European countries to NATO. The president is curing lots and lots of leftover problems that really should have been dealt with in earlier times. And it would have been easier to deal with them earlier.

Once a country's been allowed to run amuck for years and years and years, it's a lot harder for us to fix it now. But we've been doing it very systemically, one piece by one piece, and we will continue to do so.

DEANGELIS: Secretary Wilbur Ross, thank you so much and thank you for your service. Great to see you this morning.

ROSS: Thank you, Jackie. Good to be on with you.

DEANGELIS: Coming up on the program, Ford is rolling on. The carmaker weathering the Covid-19 crisis. We're going take a look at that next.

Plus, coronavirus changing air travel. Airports bracing for new safety measures.

You are watching MORNINGS WITH MARIA live on Fox Business.

DEANGELIS: Welcome back.

Ford not hitting the brakes. The automaker unveiling two new products in the last 30 days, including an updated version of the most popular car on the road, the F-150, as well as that iconic Ford Bronco.

Joining us now from outside the New York Stocks Exchange in a "First on Fox" interview, Ford Chief Financial Officer Tim Stone.

Tim, wonderful to have you with us this morning. Good morning.

TIM STONE, CIO, FORD: Good morning.

DEANGELIS: I'm wondering how important these two new releases are to the Ford brand and the vision going forward.

STONE: Well, they're very important.

And thanks for having me this morning.

Before I get started, I just want to say that we are appropriately socially distanced here as we've taken off our masks. And one of the things I'm really proud of, for the team, over the past several months, is how we've navigated this crisis and done so safely, bringing our plants back online and taking care of our communities.

We're well positioned to deliver for customers, as you said, for the upcoming launches that we have of our F-150, as well as a new Mustang Mach- E, all electric vehicle, as well as the Bronco family, the Bronco Sport, a two door and a four-door. And these are fantastic new vehicles. We look forward to introducing to customers.

DEANGELIS: Tim, I'm wondering what kind of demand you're not seeing just for the new Bronco but for your vehicles in general because you had the pandemic slow sales down, right? People were say staying home, not traveling, didn't know what was going to happen. But now, as the country starts to reopen, you've also got people saying, I'm scared to ride public transportation. I don't necessarily want to do it. I want to drive. And so I'm wondering if that translates into car sales.

STONE: Well, I think you're starting to see that. There have been some pent-up demand and we're, you know, cautious optimistic. There's still a lot of uncertainty ahead. We are cautiously optimistic. And we have great value for customers as they think about not only buying new vehicle or coming back to their own single car ownership. And I think there could be an opportunity for us ahead. We're well positioned for it not only with the new F-150, the Bronco and the Mustang Mach-E, our entire portfolio. We've been investing in our product portfolio for customers and resigning how we deliver our vehicles with human center design and we're really excited for what we have to offer our customer as they come back to their vehicles.

DEANGELIS: All right, well it's being described as the most capable SUV ever and you've got three versions of it, right, to launch in spring of 2021. The first would be the Bronco Sport. Then you've got a two door and a four door. And that mid-version is just $1,000 more than the Jeep Wrangler, which I think is very interesting because it was always looked at as a very moderately priced vehicle. So you are really competing in that space with something special.

STONE: We are. We're providing great value for customers. We also have best in class ground clearance. We have a safari-style roof experience which we think customers are going to find very compelling. And as I said, it's a great value. And we're launching the Bronco Sport this year, the end of the fourth quarter. And then the two door and four door come out in the spring.

Thus far we've already had over 165,000 reservations from customers. In fact, it surpassed our most optimistic expectations. And as a result, we're now working with our supply base and our manufacturing teams to try to build more -- find more capacity to deliver even more vehicles for customers. It's being really well received.

DEANGELIS: Tim Stone, good luck with it all. Thank you so much for joining us this morning. Great to see you.

STONE: Thank you very much.

DEANGELIS: We'll talk to use soon.

Coming up on the show, coronavirus changing air travel. Airports are bracing for new safety measures.

You're watching MORNINGS WITH MARIA live on Fox Business.

DEANGELIS: Flying safe. Airports putting new screening practices in place to lure travelers back amid the coronavirus pandemic.

Kristina Partsinevelos at Newark International Airport with more on the details of what people will face when they're trying to check in.

Kristina, good morning.

KRISTINA PARTSINEVELOS, FOX BUSINESS: Good morning, Jackie.

A tech revolution was already in play in the aviation space before the pandemic. But now airports are desperate to get travelers back here.

Take a look at this international airport. It's completely empty. There is not one booth open at the moment. And Covid-19 has brought urgency to the race to make air travel safer. So we've got completely contactless check- in, medical screenings that all could become the new norm.

But Hong Kong International Airport is taking it up a notch with full body disinfecting stalls. You step into the booth, you get sprayed with an antimicrobial spray, all done in 40 seconds so you can be on your way.

And then you've got Dubai International Airport, they have biometric cameras everywhere, thermal cameras, but they also have just invested in K- 9s, those are dogs that are being used to detect the coronavirus according to the airport. They've done already 400 tests and the accuracy rate of the dogs is about 91 percent.

So whether it's robot cleaning floors in Pittsburgh, or PPE vending machines in LAX, you've got -- I spoke to actually the chairman of the Port Authority who says that we're not going back to pre-pandemic travel.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KEVIN O'TOOLE, CHAIRMAN, PORT AUTHORITY: And so there's little contact going forward, regardless whether the Covid vaccine is out there or not. This is -- the new reform are here to stay.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

PARTSINEVELOS: Jackie, we were already -- we know that we were -- airports were already testing and using a lot of contactless options here, like this kiosk, for example. But taking it up a not, what we can expect in the future is biometric to be used so that you come here and you don't even have to touch a screen, you'd be scanning your face, your face would become your passport. You wouldn't have to touch bag drop off. You just leave your bag there. You don't talk to anyone. The same thing with gates. And so there's one pro out of all of this, less lines. Fingers crossed for that.

Back to you, Jackie.

DEANGELIS: Wow. Kristina, amazing stuff there.

Lee, I'm curious to get your reaction here because even before the pandemic we saw less bodies in the airport helping us do things. It wasn't for germ purposes per say, it was for streamlining costs. And now we're seeing this. I mean facial recognition to check in or stepping in Hong Kong into that sanitization booth, it's really remarkable.

LEE CARTER, POLLSTER AND PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY AND PARTNERS: It's amazing. When use think about that innovation that has happened since the pandemic, we've accelerated change and a pace that is unprecedented and it is extraordinary.

I think these measures are going to be very, very important symbolically for travelers to start to get comfortable going back. And so the extent that in every -- and so many of my clients are working on how to get people comfortable to come back to work, get comfortable to come back to restaurants, get comfortable to go back and do what they did before. These kinds of measures where you're talking about less interactions, you're talking about measures to keep you safe, you're talking about antimicrobial spraying, you're thinking about taking people's temperatures, all of those things go a long way to make people feel like they're going to be safer in the moment and it's going to be very, very important that the airlines together get behind this and moving forward.

And I think, you know, the Port Authority guys was right, it is absolutely no question about it that we are not going to go back to the way things were.

DEANGELIS: Real quick, Mitch, in the last 30 seconds, I'm wondering if you think that people are going say, you know what, they're making it safer. It's OK now. I'm going to go get on a plane. I'm not there yet.

MITCH ROSCHELLE, PARTNER, PWC: Well, first of all, I think people do want to travel. People definitely need a vacation. But one thing I'll tell you about air travelers, they've very resilient. I've traveled my entire career and I remember when we used to show up at an airport ten minutes before the flight was going to leaven and then those rule have changed and we -- we responded to it.

DEANGELIS: Yes.

ROSCHELLE: So I think travelers will put up with it. I think they will.

DEANGELIS: All right, still ahead, guys, weighing yourself before you eat. Chinese restaurants taking some heat for shaming patrons next hour on MORNINGS WITH MARIA live on Fox Business.

Stay with us.

urn:contentItem:5TS3-9051-JBCN-44BV-00000-00Jared Polis talks economic incentives, net neutrality and turkey2018-11-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:03:52ZLexisNexisREGIONAL NEWSJared Polis talks economic incentives, net neutrality and turkeyErnest Luning

Colorado's governor-elect Jared Polis doesn't anticipate offering big incentive packages to lure companies very often, he told Colorado Politics in an interview Friday, adding that he's "skeptical of corporate tax giveaways" and would rather cut taxes for state residents and businesses.

The Democrat discussed a range of issues in a telephone interview, including his intention to push for a state-level net neutrality policy and what kind of a mandate he believes voters handed him last week when he defeated Republican Walker Stapleton by a 10 percentage point margin. He also said he's looking forward to spending Thanksgiving with family in Colorado.

CP: Your education transition operation has been in the news this week. How much risk are you willing to take when it comes to disruption and innovation in the way government operates, especially when it comes to education? How do you bring folks along when you're doing things that are designed to make them uncomfortable?

Polis: People didn't elect me to keep doing the same darn thing. They elected me to look for innovation and bold new solutions, and that's part of my mandate. So across every area, whether it's agriculture or higher education or K-12, we're going to push the envelope to make sure the future works for Coloradans.

CP: Would you be OK with your administration keeping economic incentive packages under wraps like those that were prepared bidding for Amazon's HQ2?

Polis: I'm skeptical of corporate tax giveaways but not categorically against them in every case. I think it is likely we'll use less of them so we can return more money to taxpayers through lower taxes.

CP: How effective do you think those incentives are?

Polis: Effective in the short term, not effective in the medium or long term.

CP: How do you and Marlon approach technology as parents, considering what a key role it's played in your life?

Polis: Our kids use iPads both for education and recreation. In many ways, our kids use iPads instead of television; I don't think either of them really ever watch TV. So, as a result, they have maybe two hours of iPad time during weekends and an hour a day during the week, in addition to anything that they're doing that's academic that would be allowed above and beyond that.

CP: Do you think children are being exposed to too much tech too early?

Polis: Children have to be savvy and have to grow up to be savvy in the use of technology. Every parent has their own style. I don't think that keeping technology away from kids helps them to develop the skills they will need to navigate technology they will inevitably encounter as they get older.

CP: Does Colorado need to regulate big tech, like Facebook?

Polis: No. We need to do what we can to keep a free and open internet by protecting the neutrality of the internet. We look forward to pursuing an agenda that, in the absence of federal protection, will make sure that all content and all service have access to an open internet through net neutrality.

CP: Your position on events like the Olympics seems to be a departure from Gov. Hickenlooper, who always seemed to be looking for ways to put Colorado on the national stage. How do you plan to showcase Colorado?

Polis: Certainly it's the role of the governor to promote our state; it's one I relish. I look forward to attracting businesses to our state, both doing international trade missions as well as working to attract conferences to our state.

CP: You didn't support either Propositions 109 or 110, and neither did voters. Where are we going to get the revenue for transportation?

Polis: The voters have clearly spoken, so therefore, there are two things we know we can rule out. Those two things are a sales tax and bonding with no new revenue, respectively. The voters have said no, decisively, to those. We're willing to have a conversation about anything else with Republicans and Democrats and the business community and reading the tea leaves of what the voters have said.

CP: How urgent is it to come up with a solution by the end of the upcoming legislative session?

Polis: I've always stressed openness to using some General Fund money for transportation, but what we do in a given year is never going to even the gap in the need to build out 21st century infrastructure.

CP: You've said that you don't want to take away Coloradans' right to vote on tax increases. Do you think there are parts of TABOR that need changing?

Polis: What I ran on, and what I intend to do, is to be a convener, which means of the education community, transportation community, Republicans and Democrats, and different geographic interests across our state. We plan on beginning those discussions soon with getting everybody on board with how we can make our state more governable with better language in our state constitution.

CP: Is campaign finance reform something Colorado should try to tackle?

Polis: I hope so. I think a lot of legislators have ideas that I am fully supportive of around increased transparency. Would be happy to have that discussion. I've long been a supporter of campaign finance reform to reduce the influence that special interests have on politics. If there's bills that go in that direction, then (I'm) likely to sign them.

CP: You've said you want to bring oil and gas, local communities and environmentalists together to solve what you've referred to as underlying issues that give rise to surface conflicts. What might a solution look like?

Polis: We want to formalize the role that local communities, cities and counties, have in the siting process for oil and gas and address the concerns that neighbors have with regard to where drilling occurs near where people live or work or go to school.

CP: There's a sense that Democrats are considering the balance between having full control of state government and being able to do whatever the party decides, versus what's sometimes referred to as "overreach," like the legislative agenda that prompted the recalls in 2013. What approach do you take to that?

Polis: What I would encourage everyone to do – Republicans and Democrats – is be true to what they ran on and deliver for the people. If you ran on improving the roads, then work on that. I ran on delivering full-day kindergarten and making sure that we can achieve 100 percent renewable energy by 2040 or sooner, and so we plan on fulfilling the mandate the voters gave me, working with the legislature as well as administratively through my appointments, to get it done.

CP: Do you have a mandate to pursue universal health care?

Polis: To cover more people, absolutely, rather than less people. In the campaign this came up a number of times, where some of the policies on the other side would jeopardize people's insurance that they had today. Our mandate is to save people money on health care, pass those savings along to people who get their insurance on their own or through the employer, and expand coverage to more people.

CP: What does your family traditionally do for Thanksgiving?

Polis: We sit around the table and have a turkey with the grandparents and the cousins and have a family dinner. We're thankful for the blessing of living in Colorado and our health and our family.

So across every area, whether it's agriculture or higher education or K-12, we're going to push the envelope to make sure the future works for Coloradans.

I'm skeptical of corporate tax giveaways but not categorically against them in every case. I think it is likely we'll use less of them so we can return more money to taxpayers through lower taxes.

How effective do you think those incentives are?

Effective in the short term, not effective in the medium or long term.

How do you and Marlon approach technology as parents, considering what a key role it's played in your life?

Our kids use iPads both for education and recreation. In many ways, our kids use iPads instead of television; I don't think either of them really ever watch TV. So, as a result, they have maybe two hours of iPad time during weekends and an hour a day during the week, in addition to anything that they're doing that's academic that would be allowed above and beyond that.

Children have to be savvy and have to grow up to be savvy in the use of technology. Every parent has their own style. I don't think that keeping technology away from kids helps them to develop the skills they will need to navigate technology they will inevitably encounter as they get older.

urn:contentItem:5PYW-6K91-JBKN-B0GV-00000-00Jaron Lanier's memoir recalls a life spent in virtual reality;The digital world2017-11-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:03:52ZLexisNexisBOOKS & ARTJaron Lanier's memoir recalls a life spent in virtual realityThe digital world

An illuminating memoir about virtual reality reflects on the hubris of Silicon Valley

WHAT is virtual reality (VR)? Over 21 chapters and three appendices, Jaron Lanier, a tech pioneer, puts forward 52 definitions. Some are geeky: "a media technology for which measurement is more important than display". Others are poetic: "the technology of noticing experience itself". And a few are terrifying: "a training simulator for information-age warfare". VR is all of these things and more besides. Yet at a time when the malign influence of social media is grabbing headlines, it is the last of these that seems most urgent.

Mr Lanier is a Silicon Valley grandee. In 1984 he started the first VR firm, VPL Research, which sold early headsets and accessories, and is widely credited with popularising the term "virtual reality". He has seen the tech industry go from being a bunch of start-ups run by counterculture idealists to global companies. He now works at Microsoft.

Mr Lanier is also a critic of his industry. His first book, "You Are Not a Gadget" (2010), argued that the web was creating "digital serfs"—users who gave up their data and privacy for no monetary reward or say in the system. "Who Owns the Future" (2013) railed against the monopolistic power of big tech firms. His new book is a memoir about virtual reality and a history of how the utopian thinking of Silicon Valley has brought dysfunction and division. It will be essential reading, not just for VR-watchers but for anyone interested in how society came to be how it is, and what it might yet become.

Many books about the early days of Silicon Valley play up the hippie-meets-techie culture that shaped it. Few define that better than the dreadlocked Mr Lanier, who was raised in El Paso and educated across the border in Ciudad Juárez. After his mother died, Mr Lanier and his father moved to New Mexico and lived in tents for over two years before moving into a DIY geodesic dome. Mr Lanier skipped the end of high school and went straight to university, but did not graduate. After drifting in semi-poverty and trying various careers, he found himself in Silicon Valley.

This was not an uncommon trajectory in the Bay Area in the 1980s. Mr Lanier describes one associate as a "hippie physicist musician", another as a Wyoming rancher and rock lyricist. In those days techie culture was a subset of hippie culture. The first advice Mr Lanier was given when he moved there was: "Don't trust the suits."

Silicon Valley believed everything would improve once coders were in charge. "We better find a way to constrain people more or the world will never get more efficient," he remembers being told. "We're creating a kind of power that is much more important than money." Software, like air or sex, was meant to be "free".

Today the world's three most valuable companies are tech firms. The web is less wild and more structured. But the shortcomings of techie ideology have been exposed. The obsession with "free" nearly destroyed the music industry and continues to wreak havoc on the media. Tech firms still believe that they do not need to follow the rules—witness Uber's bruising battles with municipal authorities around the world. And the biggest, most influential firms resist any regulation that would make them responsible for the content on their platforms. Web platforms care more about the amount of time their users spend on their sites than the quality of the experience or what they consume.

Mr Lanier remains optimistic that things can be fixed, perhaps by instituting a system of small payments to users for their data or by ensuring that artists and writers are recognised and paid for their work. Human beings, not algorithms, should be at the centre of the internet economy, he says. These ideas will be familiar to anyone who has read his previous books. The business models of big tech firms are, however, too successful and too lucrative to change, so Mr Lanier's views are unlikely to prevail.

What does this mean for VR? Virtual reality will never be as widespread as the smartphone, but it will be influential. Its promise is to make experiences in computer-generated environments feel as visceral as those in the real world. It has philanthropic potential and may improve medicine and aid education. But it can also be dangerous if virtual worlds are designed to manipulate users. Mr Lanier worries that VR may go down the same route as social networks, becoming, as in another of his definitions, "the ultimate way to capture someone inside an advertisement".

But that is not a given. Although VR has flourished of late, and headsets are now available for a few hundred dollars, the industry is still in its infancy. VR is unlikely to be widely adopted for some time. Meanwhile, Western democracies are debating the merits and dangers of tech, and the need for big companies to police their platforms better. When VR goes mainstream, that debate will have intensified—and perhaps ended well.

By the time VR matures, it will be used by people who have grown up with smartphones and social media. They, Mr Lanier argues, will be more sophisticated than today's internet users, for whom it was a new technology. The next generation will see through the manipulation. It is not much of a hope to cling to, but it is something.

Perhaps the most fitting of Mr Lanier's 52 definitions of VR is that it is "a preview of what reality might be like when technology gets better". Technology is improving. Whether reality does too depends on the technologists in charge and the power of society to shape their vision.

Dawn of the New Everything.

urn:contentItem:60K1-JPW1-JBR8-5000-00000-00Jayapal on right side of history, championing independent journalism2020-08-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:03:52ZLexisNexisJayapal on right side of history, championing independent journalismDavid ChavernSpecial to The Times

The ground has shifted under the big-tech companies as the House Judiciary Committee continued its investigation into the anticompetitive activities of the dominant online platforms. The recent hearing, sixth in a series of bipartisan hearings launched last year by the Antitrust Subcommittee Chair David Cicilline, D-R.I., and then-Ranking Member Doug Collins, R-Ga., was the first time Congress has heard from the CEOs of the largest tech companies in the country: Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google. While many representatives grilled the executives on controversial and disconcerting activities that their companies engage in, U.S. Rep. Pramila Jayapal, D-Wash., emerged as a champion of independent and high-quality news journalism.

For far too long, the dominant online platforms have held news publishers in their grips, forcing them to accept imbalanced and vague terms while capturing the vast majority of user data and digital ad revenues and making it harder for publishers to deepen relationships with their readers. While the big tech companies have prospered - Google's revenues were $162 billion in 2019 and Facebook raked in $70.7 billion - news publishers are struggling to stay afloat. According to a recent UNC study, between 2005 and 2020, more than one-fourth of the country's newspapers disappeared, leaving too many communities as news deserts, and even more are at risk.

We are thankful, then, that congressional champions, such as Jayapal, are taking the anticompetitive behavior of these online platforms and the blight of journalism seriously. During the July 29 hearing, Jayapal engaged in a fiery exchange with Sundar Pichai, the CEO of Alphabet and Google. Noting the "deep urgency to protect independent journalism," Jayapal drew attention to Google's control of the digital-ad ecosystem, where Google is running the marketplace and dominates both the buy and the sell side.

As Jayapal stated, the situation allows Google to set the rates low when buying ad space from newspapers while selling high to small businesses who rely on advertising on Google's platform. This hurts both advertisers and newspapers who rely on digital ad revenues in order to keep their communities informed. This is a clear conflict of interest that should not be allowed in any marketplace. Jayapal correctly noted that the situation resembles the stock market except without regulations that would prohibit insider trading. The lack of accountability and transparency exacerbates the situation and makes it more difficult to evaluate its market-distorting effect.

In response to Jayapal's excellent questioning, Google could only offer vague platitudes. Pichai tried to highlight the $14 billion Google has reportedly paid to publishers and the company's "deep commitment" to journalism, while noting that news is a "low margin business" for Google. All of these explanations ring hollow. If Google was serious about supporting journalism, it would take news publishers' feedback and concerns seriously, engage in meaningful negotiations, and be more transparent about its pricing, policies and data.

There are multiple ways to improve the situation. The Antitrust Subcommittee's investigation is a major step forward, especially when considered together with other investigations conducted by other authorities in the United States and around the world. But these investigations and their recommendations take time to complete and implement, all the while local newspapers are fighting for their survival. And while Google and the other big tech companies could step up and take meaningful action, they are unlikely to do so. We need more imminent fixes.

The tide is turning against the dominant online platforms. No longer do they have free rein to do as they please, strengthening their control of the online marketplace, while suffocating news publishers who invest every day in providing reliable and trustworthy news to keep their communities informed. It is lawmakers like Jayapal who take the issue seriously and acknowledge the need for Congress to take decisive action who give us hope about the sustainability of high-quality journalism in America.

urn:contentItem:5VYK-P731-DXKP-J35W-00000-00Jay Greene joins as new technology reporter in Seattle2019-04-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:03:52ZLexisNexisJay Greene joins as new technology reporter in SeattleWashPostPR

Announcement from Business Editor David Cho, Deputy Business Editor Zachary Goldfarb and Technology Editor Christina Passariello:

We are thrilled to announce that Jay Greene will be The Washington Post's new technology reporter in Seattle.

As part of our expanding coverage of technology, Jay will examine how the Pacific Northwest has emerged as a major hub for cloud computing, automation and other innovations. He'll focus primarily on Amazon, as it presses into almost every arena of commerce, and Microsoft, which has made a remarkable comeback from years of legal and regulatory challenges to emerge as a leader in cloud computing. And he'll cover the consequences of the prosperity bombs big tech companies have set off in the region.

Jay has worked as a journalist in Seattle for 21 years, the last three at The Wall Street Journal, where he covered Microsoft and the cloud-computing businesses at Amazon and Google. He spent 10 years as the Seattle bureau chief for BusinessWeek magazine and has covered Amazon and Microsoft for The Seattle Times. He also worked as an investigative reporter for the tech news site CNET.

Jay has chronicled Amazon's growth strategy that often pits it against partners. He has covered the legal and cultural challenges it faced as it expanded in Europe. And he has reported on the new generation of Microsoft executives who have revitalized the company by chasing emerging markets rather than feeding off its legacy businesses.

Jay was awarded a McGraw Fellowship for Business Journalism from City University of New York, Graduate School of Journalism. And he wrote Design Is How It Works , a book on design and innovation. Jay has a master's degree in journalism from Columbia University and a bachelor's degree in English from Macalester College.

An avid skier and cyclist, Jay takes advantage as often as he can of the natural bounty the Pacific Northwest offers. He and his wife have two sons.

Jay will start May 13 and be in the newsroom for a week, so please stop by and welcome him then
